Expires: March 12, 2019 Expires: March 23, 2019
DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance) DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance)
Extension For TLDs (Top Level Domains) Extension For TLDs (Top Level Domains)
draft-kitterman-dmarc-tld-00 draft-kitterman-dmarc-tld-00
Abstract Abstract
DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and
Conformance) is a scalable mechanism by which a mail-originating Conformance) is a scalable mechanism by which a mail-originating
organization can express domain-level policies and preferences for organization can express domain-level policies and preferences for
message validation, disposition, and reporting, that a mail-receiving message validation, disposition, and reporting, that a mail-receiving
organization can use to improve mail handling. DMARC itself does not organization can use to improve mail handling. DMARC itself does not
apply to TLDs (Top Level Domains). For the subset of TLDs that apply to domains above the organizational level, such as TLDs (Top
require DMARC usage, it is appropriate to provide TLD level DMARC Level Domains). For the subset of TLDs (or other non-organizational
capability. This memo describes an extension to DMARC to enable a domains) that require DMARC usage, it is appropriate to provide TLD
subset of DMARC functionality for such TLDs. level DMARC capability. This memo describes an extension to DMARC to
enable a subset of DMARC functionality for such domains.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
DMARC [RFC7489] provides email sending organizational policy DMARC [RFC7489] provides email sending organizational policy
information to email receivers. Due to the design of DMARC [RFC7489] information to email receivers. Due to the design of DMARC [RFC7489]
and the nature of the Internet email architecture [RFC5598], there and the nature of the Internet email architecture [RFC5598], there
are interoperability issues associated with DMARC [RFC7489] are interoperability issues associated with DMARC [RFC7489]
deployment. These are discused in Interoperability Issues between deployment. These are discused in Interoperability Issues between
DMARC and Indirect Email Flows [RFC7960]. These issues are not DMARC and Indirect Email Flows [RFC7960]. These issues are not
applicable to TLDs, since they do not send mail. applicable to TLDs, since they do not send mail.

2.2. Top Level Domain (TLD) 2.2. Top Level Domain (TLD)
The global Internet Domain Name System (DNS) is documented in The global Internet Domain Name System (DNS) is documented in
numerous Requests for Comment (RFC). It defines a tree of names numerous Requests for Comment (RFC). It defines a tree of names
starting with root, ".", immediately below which are Top Level Domain starting with root, ".", immediately below which are Top Level Domain
names such as ".com" and ".us". names such as ".com" and ".us". The usage for TLD DMARC is broader
and includes all domains above the organizational level in the tree,
e.g. ".gov.uk".
2.3. TLD Operator (TLDO) 2.3. TLD Operator (TLDO)
A TLD Operator manages operations within their TLD. A TLD Operator manages operations within their TLD.
2.4. TLDO Controlled Domain Names 2.4. TLDO Controlled Domain Names
TLDO Controlled Domain Names are names in the DNS that are managed by TLDO Controlled Domain Names are names in the DNS that are managed by
TLDOs and not available for use as organizational domains (the term TLDOs and not available for use as organizational domains (the term
organizational domains is defined in DMARC [RFC7489]). Depending on organizational domains is defined in DMARC [RFC7489]). Depending on
TLD policy, these will have one (e.g. ".com") or more (e.g. ".co.uk") TLD policy, these will have one (e.g. ".com") or more (e.g. ".co.uk")
name components. name components.
2.5. Non-existent Domains
For DMARC [RFC7489] purposes, a non-existent domain is a domain name
that publishes none of A, AAAA, or MX records. This is a broader
definition than that in NXDOMAIN [RFC8020].

3.5. Section 7. DMARC Feedback
Operational note for TLD DMARC: For TLDOs, feedback for non-existent
domains is desired and useful. Because of the constraints on TLD
DMARC scope, there are not sifnificant privacy considerations
associated with this reporting (See Section 4).
4. Privacy Considerations 4. Privacy Considerations
This document does not significantly change the Privacy This document does not significantly change the Privacy
Considerations of [RFC7489]. Considerations of [RFC7489].
4.1. Feedback leakage to TLDO 4.1. Feedback leakage
With the exception of branded TLDs (e.g. ".google"), RUA and RUF Providing feedback reporting to TLDOs can, in some cases create
reports based on TLD DMARC have the potential to contain information leakage of information outside of an organization to the TLDO. There
about emails related to multiple organizations. As a result, privacy are roughly three cases to consider:
sensitive information might be leaked from a domain owning
organization to the TLDO.
This is not an issue for organizational domains that publish DMARC o Branded TLDs (e.g. ".google"), RUA and RUF reports based on TLD
policy. For such domains, the feedback reporting addresses (RUA and DMARC have the potential to contain information about emails
RUF) of the organization will be used. Since TLD DMARC is limited to related to entities managed by the organization, but since both
TLDs that mandate organizational domains publish DMARC policy, the the TLDO and the organizational domain owners are common, there is
risk of this issue is limited to organizational domains that are out no privacy risk for either normal or nxdomain reporting.
of compliance with TLD policy.
o Multi-organization TLDs that require DMARC usage (e.g. ".bank":
TLD DMARC based reports will only be generated for domains that do
not publish DMARC policy at the organizational level. For domains
that do publish the required DMARC policy records, the feedback
reporting addresses (RUA and RUF) of the organization will be
used. Since TLD DMARC is limited to TLDs that mandate
organizational domains publish DMARC policy, the risk of this
issue is limited to organizational domains that are out of
compliance with TLD policy.
o Multi-organization TLDs (e.g. ".com") that do not mandate DMARC
usage. Privacy risks for organizational domains within such TLDs
would be significant. This is mitigated by the limitation of TLD
DMARC to exclude such TLDs and the requirement for a public IANA
registry that is required to exclude such TLDs.
TLDOs will receive feedback on non-existant domains, which may be TLDOs will receive feedback on non-existant domains, which may be
similar to existing organizational domains. Feedback related to such similar to existing organizational domains. Feedback related to such
cousin domains have a small risk of carrying information related to cousin domains have a small risk of carrying information related to
an actual organizational domain. To minimize this potential concern, an actual organizational domain. To minimize this potential concern,
TLD DMARC feedback is best limited to Aggregate Reports. Feedback TLD DMARC feedback is best limited to Aggregate Reports. Feedback
Reports carry more detailed information and present a greater risk. Reports carry more detailed information and present a greater risk.

in this new sub-registry. New entries are assigned only for TLDs in this new sub-registry. New entries are assigned only for TLDs
that require use of DMARC. The requirement has to be documented in a that require use of DMARC. The requirement has to be documented in a
manner that satisfies the terms of Expert Review, per [RFC5226]. The manner that satisfies the terms of Expert Review, per [RFC5226]. The
Designated Expert needs to confirm that provided documentation Designated Expert needs to confirm that provided documentation
